pageContext.claim: “We could have -- it could have been stopped in its tracks. Unfortunately, they [China] didn't decide to make it public. But the whole world is suffering because of it.”
pageContext.analysis: One can certainly question how forthright the Chinese government was about the emerging evidence of a coronavirus, especially if it showed signs of human-to-human transmission. But information about the new virus was made public fairly quickly. The first possible case was identified in China on Dec. 1. The head of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention learned of a possible new coronavirus from his Chinese counterpart on Jan. 3, days before Chinese researchers publicly said they had identified a new virus. The first death in China was recorded on Jan. 11.
